standard_metadata.standard_description: Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $10.74$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $10.74$ | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $7\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $10.74$  | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$|   | $+$| $14 \text{ hundredths}$ $10.74$ | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $4\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $34 \text{ hundredths}$

hints.content: Let's visualize $10.74$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{10}.\maroonE7\goldE4=\blueE{10\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{7\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{4\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: Twelve squares of equal size. The first ten squares are shaded to show 10 wholes. The eleventh square is divided into ten equal parts with seven parts shaded to show 7 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with four parts shaded to show 4 hundredths.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\goldE{4\text{ hundredths}}$ to $\goldE{14\text{ hundredths}}$. So, we need to add $\goldE{10\text{ hundredths}}$ to our existing $\goldE{4\text{ hundredths}}$.  [[☃ image 4]]  $\goldE{10\text{ hundredths}} = \maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$

images.alt: Two squares, one square is divided into ten equal parts with one part shaded to show 1 tenth. A second square is divided into 100 equal parts with ten parts shaded to show 10 hundredths. An equal sign separates the two squares.

hints.content: If we use $\maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$ to add to our hundredths place value column, then we lose one tenth from our tenths column.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonE{7\text{ tenths}} - \goldE{1\text{ tenth}} = \maroonE{6\text{ tenths}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 7 columns are shaded. 1 of the shaded columns are crossed out. 3 columns not shaded.

hints.content: Now, we have $\maroonE{6\text{ tenths}}$ and $\goldE{14\text{ hundredths}} $.  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: Twelve squares of equal size. The first ten squares are shaded to show 10 wholes. The eleventh square is divided into ten equal parts with six parts shaded to show 6 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with fourteen parts shaded to show 14 hundredths.

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $10.74$ | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $7\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $10.74$  | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $\maroonE{6\text{ tenths}}$ | $+$| $14 \text{ hundredths}$ $10.74$ | $=$ | $10 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $4\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $34 \text{ hundredths}$

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $5.48$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $5.48$ | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $4\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $8 \text{ hundredths}$ $5.48$  | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$|   | $+$| $28 \text{ hundredths}$ $5.48$ | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$| $38 \text{ hundredths}$

hints.content: Let's visualize $5.48$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 7]]  $\blueE{5}.\maroonE4\goldE8=\blueE{5\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{4\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{8\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: Seven squares of equal size. The first five squares are shaded to show 10 wholes. The sixth square is divided into ten equal parts with four parts shaded to show 4 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 hundredths.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\goldE{8\text{ hundredths}}$ to $\goldE{28\text{ hundredths}}$. So, we need to add $\goldE{20\text{ hundredths}}$ to our existing $\goldE{8\text{ hundredths}}$.  [[☃ image 7]]  $\goldE{20\text{ hundredths}} = \maroonE{2\text{ tenth}}$

images.alt: Two squares, one square is divided into 100 equal parts with twenty parts shaded to show 20 hundredths. The second square is divided into 10 equal parts with two parts shaded to show 2 tenths. An equal sign separates the two squares.

hints.content: If we use $\maroonE{2\text{ tenths}}$ to add to our hundredths place value column, then we lose two tenths from our tenths column.   [[☃ image 7]]  $\maroonE{4\text{ tenths}} - \goldE{2\text{ tenth}} = \maroonE{2\text{ tenths}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 4 columns are shaded. 2 of the shaded columns are crossed out. 6 columns not shaded.

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $5.48$ | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $4\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $8 \text{ hundredths}$ $5.48$  | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $\maroonE{2\text{ tenths}}$ | $+$| $28 \text{ hundredths}$ $5.48$ | $=$ | $5 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$| $38 \text{ hundredths}$

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $8.79$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $8.79$ | $=$ | $8 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $7\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $9 \text{ hundredths}$ $8.79$ | $=$ | $8 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $6\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $19 \text{ hundredths}$ $8.79$  | $=$ | $8 \text{ one}$ | $+$| $3\text{ tenths}$ | $+$|

hints.content: Let's visualize $8.79$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 12]]  $\blueE{8}.\maroonE7\goldE9=\blueE{8\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{7\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{9\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: Ten squares of equal size. The first eight squares are shaded to show 8 wholes. The ninth square is divided into ten equal parts with seven parts shaded to show 7 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with nine parts shaded to show 9 hundredths.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\maroonE{6\text{ tenths}}$ to $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$. So, we need to subtract $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$ from our existing $\maroonE{6\text{ tenths}}$.   [[☃ image 5]]  $\maroonE{6\text{ tenths}} - \goldE{3\text{ tenth}} = \maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 6 columns are shaded. 3 of the shaded columns are crossed out. 4 columns not shaded.

hints.content: If we use $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$ from our tenths place value column, then we need to add $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$, or $\goldE{30\text{ hundredths}}$ to our hundredths place value column.  [[☃ image 3]]  $\goldE{19\text{ hundredths}} + \maroonE{30\text{ hundredths}} = \goldE{49\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equally-sized squares to show hundredths. 19 squares are shaded gold and 30 squares are shaded maroon to represent 3 tenths. A total of 49 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $8.79$ | $=$ | $8 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $7\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $9 \text{ hundredths}$ $8.79$ | $=$ | $8 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $6\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $19 \text{ hundredths}$ $8.79$  | $=$ | $8 \text{ one}$ | $+$| $3\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $\goldE{49\text{ hundredths}}$

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $3.53$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $3.53$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $5\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $3 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.53$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $3\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $23 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.53$  | $=$ | $3 \text{ one}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$|

hints.content: Let's visualize $3.53$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 5]]  $\blueE{3}.\maroonE5\goldE3=\blueE{3\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{5\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{3\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: Five squares of equal size. The first three squares are shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into ten equal parts with five parts shaded to show 5 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 hundredths.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$ to $\maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$. So, we need to subtract $\maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$ from our existing $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}}$.  [[☃ image 5]]  $\maroonE{3\text{ tenths}} - \goldE{2\text{ tenths}} = \maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 3 columns are shaded. 1 of the shaded columns are crossed out. 7 columns not shaded.

hints.content: If we use $\maroonE{2\text{ tenths}}$ from our tenths place value column, then we need to add $\maroonE{2\text{ tenths}}$, or $\goldE{20\text{ hundredths}}$ to our hundredths place value column.  [[☃ image 5]]  $\goldE{23\text{ hundredths}} + \maroonE{20\text{ hundredths}} = \goldE{43\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equally-sized squares to show hundredths. 23 squares are shaded gold and 20 squares are shaded maroon to represent 2 tenths. A total of 43 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $3.53$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $5\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $3 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.53$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $3\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $23 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.53$  | $=$ | $3 \text{ one}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$| $\goldE{43\text{ hundredths}}$

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $2.15$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $2.15$ | $=$ | $2 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$ $2.15$  | $=$ | $1 \text{ one}$ | $+$|   | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$ $2.15$ | $=$ | $0 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $21\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$

hints.content: Let's visualize $2.15$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{2}.\maroonE1\goldE5=\blueE{2\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{1\text{ tenth}} + \goldE{5\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt:
Four squares of equal size. The first two squares are
shaded to show 2 wholes. The third square is
divided into ten equal parts with one part shaded to
show 0.1. The last square is divided into 100 equal
parts with five parts shaded to show 0.05.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\blueE{1\text{ one}}$ to $\maroonE{\text{tenths}}$. So, we need to add $\maroonE{10\text{ tenths}}$ to our existing $\maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$.  [[☃ image 3]]  $\blueE{1\text{ one}} = \maroonE{10\text{ tenths}}$

images.alt: Two squares, one square is shaded to show one whole. A second square is divided into 10 equal parts with ten parts shaded to show 10 tenths. An equal sign separates the two squares.

hints.content: Now, we have $\blueE{1\text{ one}}$, $\maroonE{11\text{ tenths}}$ and $\goldE{5\text{ hundredths}} $.  [[☃ image 4]]

images.alt: Four squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with ten parts shaded to show ten tenths. The third square is divided into ten equal parts with one part shaded to show one tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with five parts shaded to show 5 hundredths.

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $2.15$ | $=$ | $2 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $1\text{ tenth}$ | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$ $2.15$  | $=$ | $1 \text{ one}$ | $+$| $\maroonE{11\text{ tenths}}$  | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$ $2.15$ | $=$ | $0 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $21\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $5 \text{ hundredths}$

question.content: **Use the table to regroup $3.64$ in a different way.**   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $3.64$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $6\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.64$  | $=$ | $2 \text{ ones}$ | $+$|  $16\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.64$ | $=$ | $0 \text{ ones}$ | $+$|   | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$

hints.content: Let's visualize $3.64$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 4]]  $\blueE{3}.\maroonE6\goldE4=\blueE{3\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{6\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{4\text{ hundredths}}$

images.alt:
Five squares of equal size. The first three squares are
shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is
divided into ten equal parts with six part shaded to
show 0.6. The last square is divided into 100 equal
parts with four parts shaded to show 0.04.

hints.content: The table shows regrouping $\blueE{1\text{ one}}$ to $\maroonE{\text{tenths}}$. So, we need to add $\maroonE{10\text{ tenths}}$ to our existing $\maroonE{1\text{ tenth}}$.  [[☃ image 5]]  $\blueE{1\text{ one}} = \maroonE{10\text{ tenths}}$

hints.content: Now, we have $\blueE{0\text{ ones}}$, $\maroonE{36\text{ tenths}}$ and $\goldE{4\text{ hundredths}} $.  [[☃ image 5]]

hints.content: Here is the completed table:   |  | | | | | - | :- | :-| :-| :- $3.64$ | $=$ | $3 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $6\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.64$  | $=$ | $2 \text{ ones}$ | $+$|  $16\text{ tenths}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$ $3.64$ | $=$ | $0 \text{ ones}$ | $+$| $\maroonE{36\text{ tenths}}$ | $+$| $4 \text{ hundredths}$

question.content: $4.65$ is $4\text{ ones} + 6\text{ tenths} + 5\text{ hundredths}$.    **What is another way to make $4.65$?**

images.alt: Six squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 4 wholes. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with six parts shaded to show 0.6. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.05.

hints.content: Let's visualize $4.65$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 7]]  $\blueE{4}.\maroonE6\goldE5=\blueE{4\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{6\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{5\text{ hundredths}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $4.65$.

images.alt: Six squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 4 wholes. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with six parts shaded to show 0.6. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.05.

hints.content: ### Expression: $4\text{ ones} + 7\text{ tenths} + 5\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $4$| $.$| $7$| $5$  $4.75 \neq 4.65$  $4\text{ ones} + 7\text{ tenths} + 5\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $4.65$.

images.alt: Six squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 4 wholes. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with seven parts shaded to show 0.7. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.05.

hints.content: ### Expression: $4\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 105\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $5$| $.$| $5$| $5$  $5.55 \neq 4.65$  $4\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 105\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $4.65$.

images.alt: Seven squares that are equal in size. The first four squares are shaded to show 4 wholes. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.5. The sixth square is divided into 100 equal parts with all parts shaded to show 1 whole. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.05.

hints.content: ### Expression: $4\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 15\text{ hundredths}$   [[☃ image 1]]  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $4$| $.$| $6$| $5$  $4.65 = 4.65$  $4\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 15\text{ hundredths}$ is another way to show $4.65$.

images.alt: Six squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 4 wholes. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with five parts shaded to show 0.5. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with fifteen parts shaded to show 0.15.

hints.content: Another way to make $4.65$ is $4\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 15\text{ hundredths}$.

question.content: $3.47$ is $3\text{ ones} + 4\text{ tenths} + 7\text{ hundredths}$.    **What is another way to make $3.47$?**

images.alt: 5 squares of equal size. The first 3 squares are completely shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into 10 equal parts with 4 parts shaded to show 4 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 7 parts shaded to show 7 hundredths.

hints.content: Let's visualize $3.47$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 7]]  $\blueE{3}.\maroonE4\goldE7=\blueE{3\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{4\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{7\text{ hundredths}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $3.47$.

images.alt: 5 squares of equal size. The first 3 squares are completely shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into 10 equal parts with 4 parts shaded to show 4 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 7 parts shaded to show 7 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 170\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $5$| $.$| $0$| $0$  $5.00 \neq 3.47$  $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 170\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $3.47$.

images.alt: 6 squares of equal size. The first 3squares are shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The fifth square is divided into 100 equal parts with all hundred parts shaded to show 100 hundredths, or 1 whole. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 70 parts shaded to show 70 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 107\text{ hundredths}$:  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $4$| $.$| $3$| $7$  $4.37 \neq 3.47$  $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 107\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $3.47$.

images.alt: 6 squares of equal size. The first 3 squares are shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The fifth square is divided into 100 equal parts with all hundred parts shaded to show 100 hundredths, or 1 whole. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 7 parts shaded to show 7 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 17\text{ hundredths}$:  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $3$| $.$| $4$| $7$  $3.47 = 3.47$  $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 17\text{ hundredths}$  is another way to show $3.47$.

images.alt: Five squares of equal size. The first three squares are shaded to show 3 wholes. The fourth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with seventeen parts shaded to show 17 hundredths.

hints.content: Another way to make $3.47$ is $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 17\text{ hundredths}$.

question.content: $6.71$ is $6\text{ ones} + 7\text{ tenths} + 1\text{ hundredth}$.    **What is another way to make $6.71$?**

images.alt: 8 squares of equal size. The first 6 squares are completely shaded to show 6 wholes. The seventh square is divided into 10 equal parts with 7 parts shaded to show 7 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 1 part shaded to show 1 hundredth.

hints.content: Let's visualize $6.71$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 8]]  $\blueE{6}.\maroonE7\goldE1=\blueE{6\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{7\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{1\text{ hundredth}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $6.71$.

images.alt: 8 squares of equal size. The first 6 squares are completely shaded to show 6 wholes. The seventh square is divided into 10 equal parts with 7 parts shaded to show 7 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 1 part shaded to show 1 hundredth.

hints.content: ### Expression: $6\text{ ones} + 6\text{ tenths} + 2\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $6$| $.$| $6$| $2$  $6.62 \neq 6.71$  $6\text{ ones} + 6\text{ tenths} + 2\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $6.71$.

images.alt: 8 squares of equal size. The first 6 squares are completely shaded to show 6 wholes. The seventh square is divided into 10 equal parts with 6 parts shaded to show 6 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 2 parts shaded to show 2 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $6\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 11\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $6$| $.$| $6$| $1$  $6.61 \neq 6.71$  $6\text{ ones} + 5\text{ tenths} + 11\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $6.71$.

images.alt: 8 squares of equal size. The first 6 squares are completely shaded to show 6 wholes. The seventh square is divided into 10 equal parts with 5 parts shaded to show 5 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 11 parts shaded to show 11 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $6\text{ ones} + 4\text{ tenths} + 31\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $6$| $.$| $7$| $1$  $6.71 = 6.71$  $6\text{ ones} + 4\text{ tenths} + 31\text{ hundredths}$  is another way to show $6.71$.

images.alt: 8 squares of equal size. The first 6 squares are completely shaded to show 6 wholes. The seventh square is divided into 10 equal parts with 4 parts shaded to show 4 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with 31 parts shaded to show 31 hundredths.

hints.content: Another way to make $3.47$ is $3\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 17\text{ hundredths}$.

question.content: $1.83$ is $1\text{ one} + 8\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$.    **What is another way to make $1.83$?**

images.alt: Three squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 hundredths.

hints.content: Let's visualize $1.83$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 4]]  $\blueE{1}.\maroonE8\goldE3=\blueE{1\text{ one}} + \maroonE{8\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{3\text{ hundredths}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $1.83$.

images.alt: Three squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $1\text{ one} + 18\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $2$| $.$| $8$| $3$  $2.83 \neq 1.83$  $1\text{ one} + 18\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $1.83$.

images.alt: Four squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 1 whole. The third square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $0\text{ ones} + 8\text{ tenths} + 13\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $0$| $.$| $9$| $3$  $0.93 \neq 1.83$  $0\text{ ones} + 8\text{ tenths} + 13\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $1.83$.

images.alt: Two squares of equal size. The first square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The second square is divided into 100 equal parts with thirteen parts shaded to show 13 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $0\text{ ones} + 18\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $1$| $.$| $8$| $3$  $1.83 = 1.83$  $0\text{ ones} + 18\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$  is another way to show $1.83$.

images.alt: Three squares of equal size. The first square is divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 hundredths.

hints.content: Another way to make $1.83$ is $0\text{ ones} + 18\text{ tenths} + 3\text{ hundredths}$.

question.content: $2.98$ is $2\text{ ones} + 9\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$.    **What is another way to make $2.98$?**

images.alt: Four squares of equal size. The first two squares are shaded to show 2 wholes. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with nine parts shaded to show 9 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 hundredths.

hints.content: Let's visualize $2.98$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 5]]  $\blueE{2}.\maroonE9\goldE8=\blueE{2\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{9\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{8\text{ hundredths}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $2.98$.

images.alt: Four squares of equal size. The first two squares are shaded to show 2 wholes. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with nine parts shaded to show 9 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $1\text{ one} + 10\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $2$| $.$| $0$| $8$  $2.08 \neq 2.98$  $1\text{ one} + 10\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $2.98$.

images.alt: Three squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 1 whole.  The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $1\text{ one} + 8\text{ tenths} + 18\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $1$| $.$| $9$| $8$  $1.98 \neq 2.98$  $1\text{ one} + 8\text{ tenths} + 18\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $2.98$.

images.alt: Three squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 tenths. The third square is divided into 100 equal parts with eighteen parts shaded to show 18 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $1\text{ one} + 19\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $2$| $.$| $9$| $8$  $2.98 = 2.98$  $1\text{ one} + 19\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$  is another way to show $2.98$.

images.alt: Four squares of equal size. The first square is shaded to show 1 whole. The second square is divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 1 whole. The third square is divided into ten equal parts with nine parts shaded to show 9 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with eight parts shaded to show 8 hundredths.

hints.content: Another way to make $2.98$ is $1\text{ one} + 19\text{ tenths} + 8\text{ hundredths}$.

question.content: $5.36$ is $5\text{ ones} + 3\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$.    **What is another way to make $5.36$?**

images.alt: Seven squares of equal size. The first five squares are shaded to show 5 wholes. The sixth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with six parts shaded to show 6 hundredths.

hints.content: Let's visualize $5.36$ using place value blocks.   [[☃ image 6]]  $\blueE{5}.\maroonE3\goldE6=\blueE{5\text{ ones}} + \maroonE{3\text{ tenths}} + \goldE{6\text{ hundredths}}$  Let's look at each expression to see which one also shows $5.36$.

images.alt: Seven squares of equal size. The first five squares are shaded to show 5 wholes. The sixth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with six parts shaded to show 6 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $4\text{ ones} + 13\text{ tenths} + 16\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $5$| $.$| $4$| $6$  $5.46 \neq 5.36$  $4\text{ ones} + 13\text{ tenths} + 16\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $5.36$.

images.alt: Seven squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 1 whole. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 1 whole.  The sixth square s divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with sixteen parts shaded to show 16 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $4\text{ ones} + 4\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $4$| $.$| $4$| $6$  $4.46 \neq 5.36$  $4\text{ ones} + 4\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$ is **not** a way to show  $5.36$.

images.alt: Six squares of equal size. The first four squares are shaded to show 1 whole. The fifth square is divided into ten equal parts with four parts shaded to show 4 tenths. The sixth square is divided into 100 equal parts with six parts shaded to show 6 hundredths.

hints.content: ### Expression: $3\text{ ones} + 23\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$  [[☃ image 1]]    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $5$| $.$| $3$| $6$  $5.36 = 5.36$  $3\text{ ones} + 23\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$  is another way to show $5.36$.

images.alt: Seven squares of equal size. The first three squares are shaded to show 1 whole. The fourth and fifth squares are divided into ten equal parts with all ten parts shaded to show 2 wholes. The sixth square is divided into ten equal parts with three parts shaded to show 3 tenths. The last square is divided into 100 equal parts with six parts shaded to show 6 hundredths.

hints.content: Another way to make $5.36$ is $3\text{ ones} + 23\text{ tenths} + 6\text{ hundredths}$.
